images.copyright: Aerial view of vineyards, Varnhalt, Black Forest, Germany (© Sabine Gerold/Amazing Aerial Agency)
images.title: A proud heritage
images.caption: Vineyards in Varnhalt, Black Forest, Germany
images.desc: The Badische Weinstraße is a picturesque route that stretches over 500 kilometres along the Black Forest, leading you through some of Germany's most beautiful wine-growing regions. In today's image, we find ourselves in Varnhalt, a charming wine village that is part of Baden-Baden. One of the region's highlights is the Nägelsförsterhof winery, which has been in operation since 1588. This vineyard is well-known for producing Riesling wines, renowned for their exceptional quality.

og.title: Vineyards in Varnhalt, Black Forest, Germany
og.desc: The Badische Weinstraße is a picturesque route that stretches over 500 kilometres along the Black Forest, leading you through some of…

images.copyright: Chimera of Notre-Dame de Paris, France (© scaliger/Getty Images)
images.title: Stone-cold stares on Halloween
images.caption: Happy Halloween!
images.desc: Do you sometimes get spooked? If you do, that means you have a healthy sense of fun and fear. And what better day of the year than Halloween to indulge in all things scary? The holiday we know today traces its roots to ancient traditions, including the Celts' Samhain, the Romans' Feralia and medieval Christian observances. Today, costumed people mingle in the streets, not unlike their ancestors who donned animal skins to divine the future or celebrate saints and martyrs.

og.title: Happy Halloween!
og.desc: Do you sometimes get spooked? If you do, that means you have a healthy sense of fun and fear. And what better day of the year than Halloween…

images.copyright: View of Edinburgh Castle from a churchyard in Scotland, United Kingdom (© Chris Dorney/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: A haunting history
images.caption: Edinburgh Castle, Scotland, United Kingdom
images.desc: If you're looking for a Halloween destination that combines history with a hefty dose of hauntings, Edinburgh Castle in Scotland is the place to be. Positioned high on an extinct volcano, these fortress walls have seen wars, royal births, executions and plenty of other drama since the 11th century. What really sets it apart is its reputation as one of Scotland's most haunted spots. It's no surprise that with more than 1,000 years of history, some have reported ghost sightings.

og.title: Edinburgh Castle, Scotland, United Kingdom
og.desc: If you're looking for a Halloween destination that combines history with a hefty dose of hauntings, Edinburgh Castle in Scotland is the…

images.copyright: Great horned owl (© Mark Newman/Getty Images)
images.title: Hoots and haunts
images.caption: Great horned owl
images.desc: The Halloween season is upon us, so let's meet one of the holiday's icons: the great horned owl. With its keen vision, eerie vocalisations and silent flight, this owl has historically been revered and feared. In folklore and mythology, owls were considered symbols of wisdom and omens of death. On Samhain, the Celtic precursor to Halloween, the owl was believed to be the kin of roaming spirits.

og.title: Great horned owl
og.desc: The Halloween season is upon us, so let's meet one of the holiday's icons: the great horned owl. With its keen vision, eerie vocalisations…

images.copyright: Pumpkin field, Victoria, British Columbia, Canada (© Shaun Cunningham/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: It's carving time
images.caption: Pumpkin field, Victoria, British Columbia
images.desc: As autumn blankets the landscape in amber hues and the chill of Halloween approaches, the time-honoured tradition of carving jack-o'-lanterns comes to life. In Canada, as Irish immigrants settled, abundant pumpkins became the ideal substitutes for the turnips and potatoes they had previously used to create lanterns. By hollowing out pumpkins and lighting them with candles, they transformed the gourds into flickering defences against evil spirits.

og.title: Pumpkin field, Victoria, British Columbia
og.desc: As autumn blankets the landscape in amber hues and the chill of Halloween approaches, the time-honoured tradition of carving jack-o…

images.copyright: Polar bear with cub, Churchill, Manitoba, Canada (© Design Pics/plainpicture)
images.title: A mother's warmth in the cold
images.caption: Polar Bear Week
images.desc: Polar Bear Week champions one of nature's greatest hunters, the Arctic's majestic predator. Established by Polar Bears International, this period highlights the challenges these mammals face due to climate change, particularly the rapid loss of Arctic Sea ice. This event coincides with the gathering of polar bears in Churchill, Manitoba—the 'Polar Bear Capital of the World'—as seen in today's image. Here, bears wait for Hudson Bay to freeze so they can start hunting for seals, their primary food source.
images.bsTitle: A mother's warmth in the cold

images.copyright: Gespensterwald, Nienhagen, Mecklenburg-West Pomerania, Germany (© mauritius images GmbH/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Mysterious woods by the sea
images.caption: Gespensterwald, Nienhagen, Germany
images.desc: In the coastal region of Mecklenburg-West Pomerania in Germany lies the Gespensterwald, which means 'Ghost Forest,' seen in today's image. This spine-tingling forest covers about 1.8 square kilometres, with its gnarled beech, hornbeam, ash and oak trees twisting toward the sky. The salty sea air from the Baltic Sea and the moist climate contribute to the trees' distorted shapes, giving rise to the forest's haunted moniker. Visitors experience light-hearted brushes with the supernatural, such as the crunch of dead leaves, a friendly spirit waving hello from afar or a mischievous ghost peeking from behind a tree. The strategic lighting, which casts ghostly shadows, along with the sculptures and decorations placed along the path, are elements that enhance the forest's ghostly aura throughout the year.

og.title: Gespensterwald, Nienhagen, Germany
og.desc: In the coastal region of Mecklenburg-West Pomerania in Germany lies the Gespensterwald, which means 'Ghost Forest,' seen in today's image…

images.copyright: Mont Blanc in Chamonix, France (© Simon Schöpf/Getty Images)
images.title: The heights of horror
images.caption: Frankenstein Friday
images.desc: Picture yourself at the highest peak in the Alps, where the air is crisp and the views are breathtaking. The towering presence of Mont Blanc, seen in this image, has left an indelible mark on literature, most notably on Mary Shelley's 'Frankenstein.' The last Friday of October is Frankenstein Friday, honouring Shelley's literary genius and the fascinating creature born from her imagination. 'Frankenstein' was conceived during a ghost story challenge. In 1816, an 18-year-old Shelley, along with fellow writers Percy Bysshe Shelley, John Polidori and Lord Byron, spent a stormy summer in Switzerland. There, she penned the tale of Victor Frankenstein and the Creature. A pivotal scene in the novel takes place on a glacier near Mont Blanc, where Victor is confronted by his monstrous creation. This setting, with its surreal beauty and treacherous terrain, perfectly captures a sense of awe and terror.
